questions.text: Which of the following is the most common surgery done for tubotympanic type of chronic suppurative otitis media?
questions.solution:
Tympanoplasty is the most common surgery done in the tubotympanic type of CSOM.

It involves ossiculoplasty (the eradication of the disease from the middle ear and repair of ossicles) with or without myringoplasty (repair of perforation of the tympanic membrane, which is done to check repeated infections from external ear).

questions.text: As a first-year ENT resident, you are preparing a patient for tympanoplasty. Which of the following would not be in your pre-operative checklist?
questions.solution:
CT scan of the temporal bone is not required in tympanoplasty procedures. It is required only in cases of mastoidectomy.

For tympanoplasty, routine blood investigations, pure tone audiometry, and an X-ray of the mastoid are sufficient.

questions.text: Wullstein’s classification is used for which of the following procedures?
questions.solution:
Zollner and Wullstein’s classification is used to classify tympanoplasty.

Related Pearl: Zollner and Wullstein’s classification/ Types of tympanoplasty

Type II Malleus eroded Over the remnant malleus/ incus
Type III (or) Columella (or) Myringostapediopexy Malleus & incus absent Over stapes superstructure

Type III is called columella because it resembles the middle ear of birds. They have a single ossicle. Type VI is not part of the original Zollner-Wullstein classification. It is a recent addition.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with complaints of painless, odourless and profuse discharge from the right ear. An otoscopic image of the affected ear is given below. Which of the following would not be a part of the management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image showing a medium central perforation of the pars tensa is suggestive of tubo-tympanic type (TTD) of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM). Canal wall down mastoidectomy is not a part of the management plan.

This is only performed in attico-antral type and in cases of tubo-tympanic type where a reservoir of infection in the middle ear is suspected.

Management of tubo-tympanic type of CSOM:

  • Medical management:
    • Aural toilet
    • Topical antibiotics with steroid drops
    • Systemic antibiotics
    • Treatment of causative factors.
  • Surgical management:
    • It is done once the ear is dry for 6 weeks without antibiotics. 
    • Tympanoplasty (ossiculoplasty with or without myringoplasty).

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common graft material used for tympanoplasty?
questions.solution:
Temporalis fascia is the most common graft material used for tympanoplasty

Other graft materials used are:

  • The areolar fascia overlying the temporal fascia
  • Perichondrium from the tragus
  • Conchal cartilage
  • Vein
  • Periosteum

Dura mater was used earlier but then discontinued due to the risk of prion diseases like Cruetzfeldt Jacob disease.

questions.text: A patient having chronic otitis media with perforation of pars tensa is scheduled for myringoplasty to restore hearing. Which of the following is true regarding the techniques used here?

choices.text: In underlay technique, graft is placed medial to annulus
In underlay technique, graft is placed lateral to malleus
In overlay technique, graft is placed medial to annulus
In overlay technique, graft is placed lateral to malleus

questions.solution:
In the underlay technique, the graft is placed medial to the annulus. Whereas, in the overlay technique, the graft is placed lateral to the annulus. The graft is medial to malleus in both techniques.

Myringoplasty techniques are based on the relation of the graft with lamina propria of tympanic membrane remnants and fibrous annulus.

questions.text: A patient with mucosal disease of the middle ear is set to undergo myringoplasty. Which of the following incisions is used here?
questions.solution:
Wilde’s (or post-aural) incision is used in myringoplasty. 

Wilde's incision is used in the following:

  • Cortical mastoidectomy
  • Modified radical and radical mastoidectomy
  • Tympanoplasty - when perforation extends anterior to handle of malleus
  • Exposure of CN VII in the vertical segment
  • Surgery of endolymphatic sac.

Option A: Killian’s incision is used in submucous resection surgery for deviated nasal septum. In cases of a deviated septum, a slightly curvilinear incision is made, 2–3 mm behind the caudal end of septal cartilage at the mucocutaneous junction, always on the left side.

Option B: Freer’s hemitransfixion incision is used in septoplasty done for deviated nasal septum. In case of caudal dislocation, a transfixion or hemitransfixion incision is made. It is a septocolumellar incision between the caudal end of septal cartilage and columella on the concave side.

Option D: Gluck–Sorenson’s incision used for laryngectomy with radical neck dissection.

questions.text: Austin’s classification for anatomical defects in the ossicular chain is based on which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Austin's classification of anatomical defects in the ossicular chain is based on the presence or absence of handle of malleus and stapes suprastructure. 

Incus is the most common bone to be eroded and assuming it to be absent in most cases, the remaining 2 ossicles, i.e., malleus and stapes are considered for the classification.

questions.text: A patient presents to your OPD with hearing difficulty and scanty, foul-smelling discharge from the left ear. Otologic examination reveals the following finding. What is the treatment of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a case of atticoantral type of CSOM and modified radical mastoidectomy is the treatment of choice here. 

Option A: Myringotomy is done in cases of acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM) and serous otitis media.

Options C and D: Medical management followed by myringoplasty or tympanoplasty once the ear is dry for 6 weeks without antibiotics is the treatment of choice for tubotympanic type of CSOM.

questions.text: What would be the primary aim of surgery in a patient presenting with the following otoscopic finding?
questions.solution: The given image shows a white mass located in the anterosuperior quadrant behind the intact eardrum suggestive of cholesteatoma. The primary aim is to clear the disease and render the ear safe. The second priority is to preserve or reconstruct the hearing, but never at the cost of the primary aim.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child with chronic suppurative otitis media and cholesteatoma is planned for a mastoidectomy. He is part of the school swimming club and wants to pursue the sport. Which of the following would you mention while counselling the parents regarding canal wall up (CWU) and canal wall down (CWD) mastoidectomies?

choices.text: Incidence of residual disease is very low not requiring second look surgery in CWU procedure
Easy to wear a hearing aid if need in CWD procedure
Post surgery healing is rapid and periodic cleaning is unnecessary in CWU procedure
The patient is allowed to swim after CWD procedure

questions.solution:
Post-surgery healing is rapid and periodic cleaning is unnecessary in case of canal wall up procedure (CWU). This procedure has a low predisposition to infection but carries the risk of leaving behind residual disease requiring the need for second-look surgery.

Canal wall up procedure (CWU) Canal wall down procedure (CWD)
Meatus appears normal 

Meatus opening is wide communication with mastoid
Does not require routine cleaning  Cleaning once or twice a year required.
High rate of recurrent or residual cholesteatoma Low rate of recurrence
Requires second-look surgery after 6 months Not required
The patient is allowed to swim. No limitation. Swimming can lead to infection of the mastoid cavity

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in a case of otitis media?
questions.solution:
Battle sign refers to retro auricular or mastoid ecchymosis that typically results from a fracture of the middle cranial fossa following head trauma. It is prominent when there is a fracture of the temporal bone. Battle sign is not seen in the case of otitis media.

Option A: Bezold abscess is a complication of acute otomastoiditis where the infection/pus breaks through the thin medial side of the tip of the mastoid and presents as a swelling in the upper part of the neck. 

Option B: Griesinger sign refers to edema of the postauricular soft tissues overlying the mastoid process as a result of thrombosis of the mastoid emissary vein seen in sigmoid sinus thrombosis. It is a complication of acute otomastoiditis.

Option D: Delta sign is a contrast-enhanced CT finding seen in sagittal sinus thrombosis, which can occur as a complication of acute mastoiditis or chronic suppurative otitis media. It is a triangular area with rim enhancement and the central low-density area is seen in the posterior cranial fossa on axial cuts. MR venography is useful to assess the progression or resolution of a thrombus. 

The image below depicts a filling defect (thrombus) outlined by contrast medium in the sagittal sinus.

questions.text: A patient complains of severe pain in his right ear associated with high-grade fever and profuse ear discharge. Clinical examination reveals mastoid tenderness and perforation of the tympanic membrane. If this infection were to burst out through the medial aspect of the tip of the mastoid, which of the following conditions would ensue?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of severe pain in his right ear associated with high-grade fever, profuse ear discharge, mastoid tenderness, and perforation of the tympanic membrane is suggestive of acute mastoiditis, which has most likely occurred as a complication of acute infection of the middle ear. If this infection is to burst out through the medial side of the tip of the mastoid, it results in the formation of Bezold abscess.

Acute mastoiditis is used to refer to an acute infection that spreads from the mucosa, lining the mastoid air cells, to involve the bony walls of the mastoid air cell system.

The image below shows a picture of acute mastoiditis:

Blood leukocytes and ESR is raised. CT scan of the temporal bone shows clouding of air cells due to the collection of exudate in them. In later stages, a cavity may be seen in the mastoid. Treatment is done by administration of intravenous antibiotics and if indicated, surgical procedures such as myringotomy and cortical mastoidectomy.

Abscesses in Relation to mastoid infection are:

  • Bezold abscess lies deep to the sternocleidomastoid and presents as a swelling in the tip of the mastoid or the angle of the jaw and is seen in the upper part of the posterior triangle or the parapharyngeal space

The images below show a picture of Bezold abscess:

 

Other abscesses in relation to mastoid infection:

  • Post auricular abscess - it is the most common abscess that forms over the mastoid. In infants and children, this presents over the MacEwen’s triangle.
  • Zygomatic abscess - infection of the zygomatic air cells. It is situated at the posterior root of the zygoma
  • Luc abscess (meatal abscess) -  the pus breaks through the bony wall between the mastoid antrum and external auditory meatus
  • Citelli’s abscess - the abscess is formed posterior to the mastoid, occupying a position more towards the occipital bone

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with a history of ear discharge in the left ear for the past 4 weeks, deep-seated ear pain for the past 1 week, and diplopia for the past 2 days. What is the most probable diagnosis in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Gradenigo’s syndrome, which occurs secondary to petrous apicitis. This is a complication of otitis media. 

The triad of Gradenigo's syndrome consists of:

  • Ipsilateral abducens nerve palsy (6th nerve palsy) - external rectus palsy
  • Deep ear/facial pain  (5th nerve involvement)
  • Persistent ear discharge (otitis media)

The incidence of this syndrome has reduced with the advent of antibiotics.

Option A-  Following acute coalescent mastoiditis the pus breaks through the bony wall between the mastoid antrum and the external meatus and forms Luc's abscess. The swelling can burst into the meatus causing otorrhea.

Options B and C- Nasopharyngeal carcinoma and trigeminal schwannoma can present with cranial nerve palsy, but they do not follow the above clinical course.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions would you expect to see Griesinger’s sign?
questions.solution:
Griesinger’s sign is seen in sigmoid sinus thrombosis. It is described as mastoid tenderness and edema, which is secondary to thrombophlebitis of the mastoid emissary vein.

However, Gradenigo's syndrome/triad is a complication of otitis media and is seen when the infection extends to the petrous apex (petrositis). The triad consists of:

  • Ipsilateral abducens nerve palsy (6th nerve palsy) - external rectus palsy
  • Deep ear/facial pain (5th nerve involvement)
  • Persistent ear discharge (otitis media)

questions.text: A patient with a history of foul-smelling ear discharge, for which he did not complete treatment now presents with complaints of fever with chills and swelling over the mastoid. On examination, there is tenderness along the jugular vein. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lateral sinus thrombophlebitis. It is an inflammation of the inner wall of the lateral venous sinus with the formation of an intrasinus thrombus.

Clinical features of lateral sinus thrombophlebitis:

  • Hectic picket fence fever with chills and rigors. This is due to septicemia. The clinical picture resembles malaria but lacks regularity.
  • Headache - In the early stage, it may be due to peri-sinus abscess and is mild. Later, it may be severe when intracranial pressure rises due to venous obstruction.
  • Griesinger’s sign - this is due to thrombosis of the mastoid emissary vein. Edema appears over the posterior part of the mastoid.
  • Papilloedema - its presence depends on obstruction to venous return. It is often seen with the right sinus (which is larger than the left).
  • Tenderness along the jugular vein - This is seen when thrombophlebitis extends along the jugular vein. There may be associated enlargement and inflammation of the jugular chain of lymph nodes and torticollis.

Investigations:

  • Blood culture 
  • CSF analysis - normal except for increased CSF pressure that helps in ruling out meningitis.
  • X-ray mastoid shows:
    • Clouding of air cells seen in acute mastoiditis.
    • Destruction of bone seen in cholesteatoma.
  • CECT shows a typical delta sign.

 

Treatment:

  • Intravenous antibacterial therapy
  • Mastoidectomy and exposure of sinus
  • Ligation of internal jugular vein
  • Anticoagulant therapy

questions.text: A patient with hearing loss has the following otoscopic finding. What is the treatment modality of choice?
questions.solution:
The image shows a cherry-red small mass of granulation tissue arising from the pars flaccida of the left tympanic membrane strongly suggesting that there is an underlying cholesteatoma in the attic area. Surgery is the treatment of choice in case of cholesteatoma.

The continuing discharge from the granulation tissue has caused the surface epithelia of the tympanic membrane to become edematous and thickened. This gives the surface of the tympanic membrane a thickened whitish appearance.

The primary aim in surgical treatment is to remove the disease and render the ear safe, and second in priority is to preserve or reconstruct hearing but never at the cost of the primary aim. Mastoidectomy is done.
